From an objective perspective there are some things Putin says that are true, while there are also things that are false. What is most revealing, however, are the things that are neither. These are things about the way he feels. Putin is very sensitive to feeling threatened, but seems to not be very perceptive of the ways his actions may make others feel threatened and what reasonable responses from those parties would be. This obviously can create spiraling feedback, precisely what he claims to wish to avoid.

For example, his opinion that the US us not able to adapt to a changing world and instead relies on aggression may have some truth to it. This is of course hypocritical though, as this conversation is happening in the context of his initiation of what is arguably the biggest conflict since WWII because he could not accept Ukraine's right to self determination as a state. His example of Ukraine being a member of the EU, thereby affecting economics of Russia's trade with Ukraine is a perfect example. Rather than "work things out and find solutions" as he says in his own words, he resorted to military force, precisely what he accuses the US and NATO of doing.

Another, which I do find some merit in on his part is being threatened by NATO. It is understandable to think that one may feel threatened by NATO's expansion if one were not part of NATO. From a game theory perspective it would have been wiser by NATO to leave this possibility of becoming a member open ended for Russia, as closing it would obviously have an aggressive appearance thereby instigating an aggressive response from him.

If you suppose another scenario than the current one, that Ukraine had been a member of NATO for over a decade and it was instead the baltic states of Latvia or Lithuania that were not currently in NATO, what would Putin's choice have then been? He most likely would have invaded Latvia and Lithuania under the pretext of some historical cultural claim and needing to protect Russia from NATO expansion. Therefore his motives are duplicitous and opportunistic. He utilizes his armed forces to assert control in an opportunistic way, precisely justifying the need for NATO given that he would not risk attacking a NATO country.

Would those have been his actions if NATO had never expanded in the first place, thereby making him feel threatened? It's hard to say. The disintegration of the Soviet Union did seem to be an opportunity to create a more pluralistic and less polarized world. It's too bad it was an opportunity lost. 

What I do find very reasonable to surmise is that a NATO country would never attack Russia. There is very little incentive to do this as it basically guarantees a large scale nuclear conflict and another world war. It is therefore perfectly reasonable to view NATO as a defensive organization. IE Finland and Sweden didn't join NATO because they want allies behind them when they execute some long standing plans to attack Russia. They joined NATO in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine as a means of guaranteeing their own security and sovereignty. Being a NATO member is simply a guarantee that others will not attack or invade your country. 

What is hard to accept as fact is that the Euromaidan protests were somehow organized at the behest of the CIA. It is an undeniable fact that protestors were killed by security forces, which Putin does not acknowledge. It seems much more reasonable to think that it was simply an organic and dynamic occurrence spurred by popular sentiment for inclusion in the EU that was further exacerbated by police killing of protestors.

@tuckercarlson / "This is complete nonsense, we must carefully look into it," Vladimir Putin commented on the inclusion of Jehovah's Witnesses in the list of extremist organizations. The corresponding question was asked to him at a meeting of the Council for the Development of Civil Society and Human Rights, which was held in Moscow on December 11, 2018. "We have to be much more liberal at some point... Treat all religions equally. [We should not] be enrolled in some kind of destructive... Jehovah's Witnesses are a Christian religion whose beliefs are based on the Bible.

The name means that believers “witness” to the people around them about God through words and deeds. Jehovah is the revealed name of God, the Creator of all things, in the Bible. Jesus Christ for Jehovah's Witnesses is the Savior, the Son of God, the Mentor and the Heavenly King. They follow his teachings in their lives.

By 2017, when the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation banned the activities of all 396 registered organizations of Jehovah's Witnesses in Russia, 175,000 people actively practiced this religion in the country, and a total of approximately 300,000 Russians attended their services at least once a year. Worldwide, the number of those who attend meetings of Jehovah's Witnesses reaches more than 21 million. The Russian authorities issued the first permission for religious activity back in 1913. After the era of Soviet repressions had ended, Jehovah's Witnesses received official registration in Russia in 1992. Thereafter, their meetings for worship were attended by up to 290,000 people. In 2017, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation liquidated all legal entities and confiscated hundreds of religious buildings. Searches began, and hundreds of believers were sent to jail. In 2022, the ECHR exonerated Jehovah's Witnesses and ordered Russia to stop their criminal prosecution and to compensate them for all the harm caused. The court banned the activities of 396 registered and operating Jehovah's Witnesses organizations. This decision has been challenged in the European Court of Human Rights.

The statement of the Presidential Council for the Development of Civil Society and Human Rights of 20.06.18 says: "This decision of the [Supreme] Court contains an exhaustive list of legal entities subject to liquidation. At the same time, the court's decision does not contain conclusions about the ban on the religion of Jehovah's Witnesses as such."

Is it allowed in Russia to practice religion without forming a legal entity? Yes. Jehovah's Witnesses have lived in Russia for more than a hundred years, and for most of that time they practiced their faith without the organizations that emerged in the late 1990s under the Freedom of Conscience Law and lasted less than 20 years. The presence or absence of such organizations does not mean the prohibition of entire religions, and even more so does not give grounds for criminal prosecution of citizens for their beliefs.

Is it possible to ban people, ideas, beliefs, thoughts, and feelings? This is both impossible and unacceptable. According to Article 28 of the Constitution of the Russian Federation, everyone has the right "to freely choose, have and disseminate religious and other beliefs and to act in accordance with them." This right extends to believers of all views and beliefs, including Jehovah's Witnesses. No court in Russia has ever recognized the religion or beliefs of Jehovah's Witnesses as criminal. Such a decision would be discriminatory and unconstitutional.
